thread.title: Drone comes as close as 50 metres to plane above London City Airport

author: Ollie Gillman for MailOnline
title: Drone comes as close as 50 metres to plane above London City Airport
text:
138 shares 69
View
comments
A drone was just 50 metres away from colliding with a passenger plane in a 'possibly catastrophic' near miss above London City Airport.
Both the pilot and co-pilot of the twin-engined Dash 8 aircraft, which can carry up to 78 passengers, spotted the drone as it passed along the right-hand side of the plane on April 19.
A report by the UK Airprox Board - which probes near misses - gave the close call its second highest risk rating of B, where 'safety is not assured'.
A drone was just 50 metres away from colliding with a passenger plane (file picture of a Dash 8 plane) in a 'possibly catastrophic' near miss above London City Airport
Both the pilot and co-pilot of the twin-engined aircraft, which can carry up to 78 passengers, spotted the drone (file picture) as it came within mere metres of the plane
The Dash 8 jet's pilot said the severity of the incident was 'possibly catastrophic', according to the report, and a passenger on board also saw the drone.
Investigators were unable to identify the owner of the drone, which was flying at the same altitude as the plane.
The report added that while there was no radar information for the drone, it was clear the pilots had seen it 'at close quarters'.

Share this article Share 'When the aircraft was approximately three miles south of London City Airport...the pilot reported seeing a drone at approximately 200m range and at the same height of 2,000ft,' the report said.
'The pilot reported the incident to air traffic control at the time. After landing the pilot and co-pilot, who had also seen the object, agreed that the miss distance was likely to be 50-150m and that the object was at least 1m in size, was black and white in colour and had some letters on it.
'A query to London City Tower after landing confirmed that they had had a similar report but not on that day. A passenger on the aircraft also reported seeing a black and white object. A review of the radar did not show any contact in the vicinity.'
'Possibly catastrophic': The two aircraft came within 50m of colliding above London City Airport in April
The Airprox board found there were numerous parks in the areas that could have been used to operate the drone from.
It added: 'The Board noted, as it had done for many other recent Airprox involving drones, that the drone should not have been at 2,000ft altitude anyway, let alone in the vicinity of London City Airport.
Laws on using drones state that they must not fly higher than 400ft and must not be further than 500m away from the pilot.
They also cannot be flown within 150m of any other congested area, or within 50m of other aircraft or vehicle.
